introduction.p: An equation is just a mathematical statement that two expressions are equal. Equations relating two variables are particularly useful. If we know the value of one of the variables, we can find the corresponding value of the other variable by solving the equation.

statement.p: The equation w = 6h gives Loren's wages, w, in terms of the number of hours she works, h. How many hours does Loren need to work next week if she wants to earn $225?

introduction.p: To solve an equation we can generate simpler equations that have the same solutions. Equations that have identical solutions are called equivalent equationsequivalent equations. For example, 3x - 5 = x + 3 and 2x = 8 are equivalent equations because the solution of each equation is 4. Often we can find simpler equivalent equations by undoing in reverse order the operations performed on the variable.

subsection.title: Solving Linear Equations
subsection.p: Linear, or first-degree, equations can be written so that every term is either a constant or a constant times the variable. The equations above are examples of linear equations. Recall the following rules for solving linear equations.

li.p: We can add or subtract the same number on both sides of an equation.
We can multiply or divide both sides of an equation by the same number (except zero).

subsection.p: Applying either of these rules produces a new equation equivalent to the old one and thus preserves the solution.
We use the rules to isolate the variable on one side of the equation.
The following steps should enable you to solve any linear equation. Of course, you may not need all the steps for a particular equation.

li.p:
Simplify each side of the equation separately.
Apply the distributive law to remove parentheses.
Collect like terms.
By adding or subtracting appropriate terms on both sides of the equation, get all the variable terms on one side and all the constant terms on the other.
Divide both sides of the equation by the coefficient of the variable.

subsection.title: Formulas
subsection.p: A formulaformula is an equation that relates several variables. For example, the equation P = 2l + 2w gives the perimeter of a rectangle in terms of its length and width.

statement.p: The formula ~5F = 9C + 160~ relates the temperature in degrees Fahrenheit, F, to the temperature in degrees Celsius, C. Solve the formula for C in terms of F.
Solve ~3x - 5y = 40~ for y in terms of x.

subsection.title: Linear Inequalities
subsection.p: Inequalities that include the symbols \gt or \le are called strict inequalitiesstrict inequalities; those that include \ge or \le are called nonstrictnonstrict.

If we multiply or divide both sides of an inequality by a negative number, the direction of the inequality must be reversed. For example, if we multiply both sides of the inequality 2\lt 5 by -3, we get \alert{-3}(2) \amp\gt \alert{-3}(5)\amp\amp \blert{\text{Change inequality symbol from }\lt \text{ to }\gt.} -6 \amp\gt -15
Because of this property, the rules for solving linear equations must be revised slightly for solving linear inequalities.

li.p: We may add or subtract the same number to both sides of an inequality without changing its solutions.
We may multiply or divide both sides of an inequality by a positive number without changing its solutions.
If we multiply or divide both sides of an inequality by a negative number, we must reverse the direction of the inequality symbol.

subsection.p: A compound inequalitycompound inequality involves two inequality symbols.

subsection.title: Interval Notation
subsection.p: The solutions of the inequality in form an interval. An intervalinterval is a set that consists of all the real numbers between two numbers a and b.

The set -2 \le x \le 2 includes its endpoints -2 and 2, so we call it a closed intervalclosed interval, and we denote it by [-2, 2]. Its graph is shown in figure (a). The square brackets tell us that the endpoints are included in the interval. An interval that does not include its endpoints, such as -2 \lt x \lt 2, is called an open intervalopen interval, and we denote it with round brackets, (-2, 2). Its graph is shown in figure (b).

warning.p: Do not confuse the open interval (-2, 2) with the point (-2, 2)! The notation is the same, so you must decide from the context whether an interval or a point is being discussed.

subsection.p: We can also discuss infinite intervalsinfinite intervals, such as ~x\lt 3~ and ~x\ge -1~, shown in the figure below. We denote the interval ~x\lt 3~ by (-\infty, 3), and the interval ~x\ge -1~ by [-1, \infty). The symbol \infty, for infinity, does not represent a specific real number; it indicates that the interval continues forever along the real line.

Finally, we can combine two or more intervals into a larger set. For example, the set consisting of x\lt -1 or x\gt 2, shown below, is the unionunion of two intervals and is denoted by (-\infty,-2) \cup (2,\infty).

subsection.p: Many solutions of inequalities are intervals or unions of intervals.

statement.p:
Write each of the solution sets with interval notation and graph the solution set on a number line.

x \ge -9
x\le 1 ~~\text{ or }~~ x\gt 4

li.p: [3, 6). This is called a half-openhalf-open or half-closedhalf-closed interval.
[-9,\infty). We always use round brackets next to the symbol \infty because \infty is not a specific number and is not included in the set.
